The second floor has a small bar, where you basically just stand there waiting around in what feels like the middle of a dining room, being given little direction as to where to turn and basically huddling over surrounding diners' tables feeling a little bit like a creep. The third floor feels like a hipster great room, with random chairs scattered around and a pool table. I always find myself feeling that I am at a fairly dull house party in someone's cramped row home. 

I'm just confused what all the hype is about surrounding this place. Not a number one choice of mine, and not an overly conducive environment for maintaining a good conversation or meeting folks.

poi.name: Termini Bros Bakery
poi.text: Oh my goodness, the cannoli!  Just amazing.  Simply amazing.  There's not much more to say than that.

poi.name: Federal Donuts
poi.text:
After years of hype, I've finally tried Federal Donuts! They're good as donuts go--not greasy, kind of cake-y but not dense.

We got one of each flavor and shared them as a group back at home. Without knowing which donut was which, it was honestly hard to tell what flavors they were on the ones dipped in flavored sugars. The flavors weren't terribly strong. I liked the chocolate donut best.

Next visit, I look forward to trying their chicken.

poi.name: Octopus Falafel Truck
poi.text:
Finally made it to the famed falafel truck.  I believe the official name is Christos's Falafel.  I'd heard the stories and knew that I should plan to wait and just trust in what he is serving.

Turns out you don't even order here.  Little was said to anyone during my visit.  "Gus" cooks, refills the charcoal in his grill, and serves up falafel, grilled chicken, and salads/sides.  There's no menu. Walk up to the truck, and he'll put together a styrofoam container of everything unless you specify that you want a sandwich.  Otherwise, you need not say a word.  He didn't even ask me for money, assuming I already knew the price (it's not posted anywhere).  

My plate was $10 and could easily feed two.  The chicken was flavorful, covered in spices. The salad was fine, with fresh green lettuce, a bean dish, and something tropical I couldn't identify (was that plantain?).  My palate was confused after all the Greek-style meat.

But the falafel...oh, the falafel.  It was unlike anything I've eaten.  It was so bright--there are a lot of fresh herbs in there.  It was light and airy yet crispy on the outside. The texture was unusual but excellent.  I can't for the life of me figure out what it is that makes it so different. Does he whip the bean mixture first?   Whatever it is, it works.

poi.name: Las Cazuelas Restaurant BYOB
poi.text:
Great mole!  We ordered the mole negro and a HUGE appetizer plate.  Both were delicious.  The mole was thick and flavorful and pretty close to some of the Oaxacan restaurants in LA that I miss so much.  I was so happy to find authentic Mexican food in Philly that tastes good.  Horchata was not on the menu, but something made me ask.  After all they had other aguas frescas.  Our waiter said, "let me check."  He came back with two horchatas for my friend and me.  Wahoo!  

Las Cazuelas is a BYOB, so stop off for some Negra Modelo or tequila before you get there.  But do visit.  It's not cheap Mexican food, but it is delicious.  The atmosphere is nice (it could even be a nice date spot), and the staff are great.

UPDATE: horchata is still not on the menu, but it's there if you ask for it.  The mole poblano was good, as were the shrimp and beef dishes we ordered.

poi.name: Gilbert Dental Care
poi.text:
I've moved to Massachusetts, but I come back to Philly often, so I keep coming back to Dr. Gilbert.  At the risk of sounding like I'm being paid for this, let me say that every person in Dr. Gilbert's office is friendly and professional. They all do great work, whether it is the hygienist, the dental assistant, the administrative staff who make appointments and process paperwork, or Dr. Gilbert himself.  Mari made my teeth look great and gave me some good advice to use between cleanings.  Dawn makes sense of even the most complicated of insurance processes and gets it done quickly.

There are TVs and headphones if you need distraction, and even free wifi (though I've never had to wait more than a moment in the waiting room).

Several of my co-workers now go to Dr. Gilbert on my recommendation, and they are all pleased with the results.

poi.name: Odunde
poi.text:
Apparently, Odunde, Inc does many things.  The only thing that I've experience is the Odunde festival, held in June on South Street near Grays Ferry.

Like many ethnic festivals, there were vendors selling trinkets.  but there were also lots of African and African-American themed products.  Lots of Caribbean and soul food for sale, and great entertainment.  There were capoeira, drumming circles, African dance, breakdancing, and even hip hop dance by some adorable girls from a local dance troupe.  Authors were on hand to sell their books.  There were hair stylists doing amazing things and beautiful clothing for sale.

I'm told Odunde hosts the biggest African American heritage festival in the US.  It was definitely packed with people.  

Check it out next June!  (As you can see by my photo, you don't have to be African American to have a great time at the festival!)

poi.name: Marathon
poi.text:
I was craving a salad, but I wanted a specific kind of salad.  A friend recommended we try Marathon.  I saw the menu and found a few salads that looked good.  Then, when we sat down, they handed us the "control freak" menu.  There are a few categories (burgers, salads, etc.).  In the salad section, there is a list of greens, veggies, and various ingredients/toppings/cheeses.  I was able to design the very salad I wanted: mixed greens, grilled veggies, feta cheese.  It was fabulous!  

I went back another day for a hearty, yummy burger.  The fries were fresh-cut potatoes.  

Marathon might become one of my favorite spots in Philly.  I'm a sucker for fresh, well-prepared food.  It need not be fancy.

poi.name: Olde City Food Market
poi.text: Convenient.  Cheap sandwiches in the deli.  Otherwise, just a run of the mill convenience store.

poi.name: La Colombe Coffee
poi.text:
The coffee is delicious.  No matter where I am in the city, I look for La Colombe when I want coffee.

My review is for the coffee, for the roasters.  

My review for the coffeehouse off Rittenhouse Square?  One star.  I will not go in there again.  At La Colombe, they must train their staff to look down their noses at customers and be curt and rude. I agree with previous reviews about the "euro-snobbery."  Too bad, because I like this location and love their coffee

poi.name: The Black Sheep Pub & Restaurant
poi.text:
Great pub!  Good selection of beers.  Nice staff.  The food is always fresh and delicious.  The burgers are wonderful and HUGE.  The garlic fries are giant wedges of potato fried and smothered in chopped garlic and herbs.  So much garlic that they are not for the faint of heart!  They smell so good that others in the bar came by to ask what we had.  

Skip the hummus.  It's not bad, but you can get better elsewhere and they do other things better.  Same for the sambal chicken wings.

But do remember the garlic fries.

poi.name: Good Karma Cafe
poi.text:
Oh Philly, I miss you and your indifferent baristas. I promised my niece that we'd go out for coffee when I was visiting, and we decided to hit the city. This place is open late on weekends, so we grabbed some cookies and coffee and settled in to talk about college and internships. It wasn't crowded--just a few folks with laptops. 

The space is pretty big, with plenty of room to work or socialize. The coffee is fine. The pastries are fine. And that's really all there is to say.

poi.name: Jamaican Jerk Hut
poi.text:
We went on a Monday, so no crayons, w/butcher paper, no lights in the backyard.  But it wasn't crowded and we got our food quickly.

Our server recommended the coconut shrimp, and I'm so glad we took his recommendation.  They were fresh and delicious.  The shrimp are delivered fresh every day and prepared on-site.  No frozen coconut shrimp here!

We ordered homemade ginger brew, which was thick and pulpy with fresh ginger.  It was quite strong and spicy--not for the faint of heart.  If you can't handle a lot of ginger, stick to the bottled ginger soda.

For dinner, I got the escovish fish filet.  It too was hot, peppery, and strong with vinegar.  I hiccuped for a while after the first bite (spicy food does that to me), but it was great.  I've has escoveitched fish before, but this was not as wet.  Just different.  The side dishes of Jamaican cabbage and rice & peas were so good!  Coconut milk in the rice makes all the difference, I think.

My friend got the jerk chicken (dark meat) which was also delicious.  There was a lot of meat on that plate for a leg and thigh combo!  The sauce was thick and tasty, sweet but spicy.

We also shared some 'greens, greens, greens,' and I'm glad we did.  Collards, spinach, and calaloo with coconut milk is a combination made in heaven.  

By the time we finished (yes, we ate it ALL) our generous portions of dinner, we had no room for dessert.  Our server told us they bring the desserts in from Jamaica.  They had lemon cake, rum cake, chocolate cake, and more.  Next time I'll remember to bring half of my food home and save room for dessert.

poi.name: Tria Cafe Wash West
poi.text:
On a recent trip back to Philly, we stopped in at the end of our day of travel. I got a great glass of wine, and my companions each had a really good beer. Just as I remembered it, the selection was good, prices were reasonable, and the organization of the drink list (though it might seem a bit tongue-in-cheek) makes it easier to choose a beverage.

Places like Tria--an excellent bar that would be a standout in any city but seems par for the course in a food/drink-focused place like Philadelphia--make me want to move back NOW.  Why didn't I go to happy hour here all the time when I lived here before?!

poi.name: Ants Pants Café
poi.text:
The food was good.  The coffee is strong.  The service was not very attentive.  It was a bit slow, and we never got a refill on our coffee with breakfast.  We heard the other waiter ask his table if they wanted more, but we could never find our waiter.  It was busy, but the other waiter's tables seemed okay.

The custard donut is a fried piece of heaven.  The custard was eggy and delicious.  We tried a bagel with Vegemite (this being an Aussie restaurant, we wanted something distinctly Australian).  It was a bit harsh to me, maybe an acquired taste.  The egg scrambles were good, with fresh ingredients like dill and spinach and granny smith apples.

I'd give it a try again, but at a less-busy time than Sunday brunch.

UPDATE:  Two more visits, and still mediocre service.  The food was well-prepared and tasty (loved the potato chip fries!), but it's been removed from my brunch list.  Once our meals were delivered, our server never returned.  No refills on coffee or water.  No checking in on us.  The place is pretty small, so it's hard to miss a table.  We had to flag someone down when we needed something (there was a problem with our order).  Service isn't awful, but for a $9 breakfast, I expect a bit more.

poi.name: Gilbert Dental Care
poi.text: Wait.  How did I not review this already?  Appointments are at convenient times.  Staff is helpful and filed my paperwork so that I got reimbursed quickly by insurance.   They are always on time, and their estimate of time needed for each appointment is spot-on.  They give estimates, don't pressure you to have unnecessary work, and do a great job.  People compliment me on my teeth, and they have no idea how much work went into it because it looks natural. I'm plagued by dental problems (bad genes, a dentist told me).  Gilbert makes everything so much easier.  After my first visit they all knew my name and treated me like family.

poi.name: Anthropologie
poi.text: The flagship store of a great born-in-Philly chain.  Anthropologie has some of the most wonderful merchandising of any store I know.  The displays are gorgeous.  And this location is no exception, with some displays spilling out of the building (remember those balls of yarn?).  The building is beautiful, and the merchandising can make it feel like you are walking through a fancy boutique in someone's home.  I hate shopping, but wandering this place is fun.  Like most other reviewers, I don't really shop here unless I find a bargain in the sale section. But if I ever come into an upper-middle class tax bracket, I'd like to shop here more often.

poi.name: Red Hook Coffee & Tea
poi.text:
I have found my favorite coffee house in Philly.  It is Red Hook.  

Red Hook is on Fabric Row, below the noise of South Street.  A member of the Independents Coffee Cooperative, you'll get great fair trade coffee here.  The sandwiches are fresh, prepared with high quality ingredients.  There are veggie and vegan options.  There are also sweets, which I'm told come from Homemade Goodies by Roz (a favorite bakery of mine).  

Aside from fair trade coffee, I read that they are socially responsible in many ways, including recycling coffee grounds for local farmers (that's so AWESOME) and recycling everything else they can.

Try the ancho chile hot chocolate, which is sweet and spicy and rich. that alone will keep me coming back for more!

The cafe itself is comfortable, with good music that's not too loud.  There is a counter with tall chairs, as well as tables and a sofa.  Local art shows on the walls.  There is free wireless, if that's your thing.  

I love this place.  I almost hate to review it--I want it to be my secret.

poi.name: Loews Philadelphia Hotel
poi.text:
"It's like they appreciate our business and want us to have a good stay!"

That's what the bf said when I presented him with a loaner umbrella from the front desk during our visit. From the meyer lemonade a check-in to the super-simple email checkout, we had a great stay here. I'd always loved the PSFS building and was glad to have a reason to book a room.

We booked two double beds for three people. Beds were comfortable. Our room came with a mini-fridge and usual toiletries, plus the Keurig coffee maker (which we eschewed for trips to Last Drop and Reading Terminal Market for La Colombe and Old City Coffee). 

Parking is steep, but as former residents of Philadelphia we knew that we could walk a few blocks south and park overnight for free. That saved us over $40/night.

We didn't use the gym or spa. I used the business center to print boarding passes, but only that is free. Otherwise, you must pay to use the computers, which was disappointing. WiFi is also about $14/day, so I just used my phone's mobile network. 

In all, I had a great stay and look forward to returning.

poi.name: Honey's Sit-N-Eat
poi.text:
One of my favorite breakfasts in the city.  Despite the claim, it's not as Southern or Jewish as you'd expect.  But it IS fresh and delicious!  I recommend the enfrijoladas (just like Bubbie made?).  If you get toast with your breakfast, try the homemade preserves on the table.  I had an amazing blueberry concoction on my last visit. Our server said it was just blueberries, sugar, and a few other ingredients.  So good!  The 'latke' is unlike any latke I've seen, but it is a triangle of fried potato/onion/cheesy goodness.  I have yet to visit for anything but brunch, but the lunch options look good, too.  Lots of fresh ingredients and interesting recipes.  And I hear that they'll be opening for dinner soon, too!

If you see a line outside, get on the list anyway.  It's well worth the wait!

poi.name: Essene Market & Café
poi.text:
The soups in the cafe are delicious.  That said, the rest of the store is overpriced.  I agree with the other reviews that say they are prohibitive.  Many of the products can be found at Trader Joe's for much less. The stuff that you can't find at Trader Joe's are unique items that should not be only for those with lots of disposable income.  $10 for a takeout lunch from the refrigerator section is ridiculous.  

But they do have a nice selection of fresh, quality foods.

poi.name: Shibe Vintage Sports
poi.text:
While visiting the region, my husband and I wanted to stock up on some Gritty gear for us and a friend. Not far from where we stayed, we saw some cool shirts and a sign reading, "your one-stop for all things Gritty." BAM. 

Their collection is great, and the employees were friendly and helpful. I scored a shirt celebrating an old WHA hockey team that played in my hometown area for a minute. Best part is that the Jersey Knights logo features a chess piece that looks like a reference to a certain football horse, and the colors are blue/orange like the team in my current town of Denver.

There were fun Gritty shirts too. Gritty as Run DMC? Yes, please. And stickers. And some vintage trading cards. And a shirt that says "I-G-G-L-E-S." Loved it.

Fun store with neat shirts you won't find elsewhere.

poi.name: Vineyards Cafe
poi.text: All the crepes I've tried are fantastic. The coffee is very good, though I wish they had larger sizes available. Looks tiny from the outside there is comfortable seating in the basement.

poi.name: Zaika
poi.text: We've eaten here 3 times and it seems that each time it gets even better! I had the shrimp malabar the last time and it was like a spiritual experience. Wonderful! The Naan  is always good and the service is quite attentive. It's hard to believe that this place isn't packed every time we go since this area of NE is pretty sparse on Indian.

poi.name: B & W Locksmith
poi.text: James from B&W answered the phone promptly and was at my house a hour later. He changed my locks for a very reasonable price and with a pleasant demeanor. I will definitely use B&W again!

poi.name: Cafe Square One
poi.text: Consistently a good spot for lunch, whether pickup or ordering in.  Solid food, quick to make it, can order through Yelp directly.  Labeling of food for pickup sometimes off slightly, but that's a slight problem that can usually get solved easily at time of pickup.

poi.name: Jong Ka Jib
poi.text:
Been here multiple times over the last 2 years.
Seems as if tofu isn't quite as good as it was when I started coming here.  Not sure if it's actually changed, or our tasting of it.

poi.name: Cafe Square One
poi.text: Great spot for lunch. Havent eaten in yet, came and ordered lunch twice, ordered online thru yelp once. Tasty enough and efficient. Favorite quick lunch in area with Mrs k gone

poi.name: Ken's Seafood Restaurant
poi.text: Good place, food's better than a lot of the other places with karoake rooms around Chinatown.  Stayed here 5 hours last time we had dinner.  I guess it helps that I know the owner.  Well worth it anyway, all things considered.

poi.name: Bitar's
poi.text:
Great stuff.  Good falafel (with hot sauce).  Good baklava.

Only lament, inflation.  What used to be the cheapest lunch at $2 is now among the cheapest @ $2.75 or so.

poi.name: Cousin’s Supermarket
poi.text:
Great stuff overall, prices way cheaper than other places, got the $39.99 meat special (#1), the #3 lunchmeat special, and 10 8oz cans of tomato sauce for $1, among other deals.

Produce quality wasn't too bad at all, seafood wasn't fresh enough, so I didn't get any of that.

Well worth stopping by.

poi.name: HipCityVeg - University City
poi.text: This is a great vegan place to come and dine. When I walked in I thought the place was especially clean and welcoming. Everything I've tried from this place I thought was delightful. I have had the chicken burger, ziggy burger, their smoothie and the sweet potato fries. If all vegetarian food tasted this good, I would seriously consider becoming one.

poi.name: Penang
poi.text:
I use to be obsessed with this place when I first discovered the foods in Chinatown. After immersing myself in Chinatown and trying all the diverse foods, this place is still one of my favorites. I probably came here a little too much, to the point where the people recognized my voice on the phone. Do give this place a try if you are in the area and up for Malaysian or Cambodian food. I still come visit this place from time to time.

When I come, I get my regular beef tripe curry and Hainanese Chicken to share with friends. The waiters are friendly and do their best to understand you. English is not their first language, so sometimes its better just to point at the words and pictures on the menu. I like the atmosphere here, it can fit almost any occasion. Good for large groups, dates, causal gatherings, dinner with coworkers.

poi.name: Copabanana
poi.text: Terrible experience. Had a cover fee to take advantage of Erin express crowd. I wouldn't come here again. Also, they automatically add tip on your bill, so no need to extra tip.

poi.name: Han Dynasty
poi.text:
Gotta say this is one of my favorite places in the city for Asian food. It's great for groups and the staff is super friendly. The food is deliciously and authentic. Something special that Han Dynasty that most Asian restaurants do not do, is that they make their rice fresh. Most Asian places will make a large patch and serve it through the day. I like how this place is able to delivery spicy and you're able to custom the level of spiciness.

Tip: you can park in the parking lot in the back of the building shared with Upenn. Just show your parketing ticket to Han Dynasty and they will reimburse your ticket

poi.name: Bubblefish
poi.text:
Pros: 
new sushi place in town
also a drink shop
Upbeat environment 
Free wifi! 

Cons:
Super long waits even when the whole place is empty 
Sushi is okay
Inattentive service

poi.name: Han Dynasty
poi.text: This place still serves good food but the service here definitely needs some work. Every single time I get take out, they won't give me any utensils unless I ask. When I do ask for them, they hand it to me without putting in a bag. Am I suppose to just carry a fork while I drive home to eat?

poi.name: Lloyd Whiskey Bar
poi.text:
I stopped in the evening of St. Patty's just to check this place out & see what they have to offer.  A "Whiskey Bar" it is!  A nice wooden bar to your left upon walking in, with small tables dispersed around the perimeter of the restaurant.   They offer a solid selection of whiskey & bourbon at reasonable prices.  The bar staff was very knowledgeable and will help you make a decision if your not a connoisseur. 
  I toyed with the idea of going with a whiskey flight but I was tight on time.  My experience was great, and I look forward to going back here to explore their food options.

poi.name: Honey's Sit-N-Eat
poi.text:
This spot is always packed for brunch on the weekends & for understandable reasons.  The menu selection is ginormous & almost everything is delicious.  I find myself unable to finish virtually every plate I have ever ordered here because the portions are massive.  The fresh squeezed orange juice, though a little pricey is my fav.  Give me a bucket of it any & everyday.  
  Requirements to work here...more than 70% of your wardrobe must be second hand, have at least 2 unfinished pieces of ink, and thick framed glasses must be worn by at least one employee at all times.  The spot is quaint and the tables are a little tight, but all in all it is a great spot to grab some grub.  I usually elect to go here for brunch/lunch on weekdays because the usually isn't a wait.  Even if there is, it won't be more than a few minutes.

poi.name: HipCityVeg
poi.text:
Soooo after hours of riding my bike around the city I decided to stop in & grab some lunch yesterday...great decision.  I elected to go with the "Fajita Wrap," HOLY MY PANTS GOT TIGHT!  Every single bite was delicious.  Hearty, filling, and everything I needed/wanted it to be.  Not only was it delicious, it was very well crafted.  Crafted so well that I was able to consume the entire thing without letting any of the wrap fall apart.  
  The staff was also super friendly. I look forward to going back to explore the rest of the menu.

poi.name: El Camino Real
poi.text: I was a fan of this place until i wound up getting food poisoning after going with a group of friends.  Granted the place is nice, and there is a ton of outdoor seating which is great for those glorious days, but I don't foresee myself eating here anytime soon.  I'll go back and grab a drink or 2, but it will take a lot to get me to try the food again.

poi.name: Cantina Dos Segundos
poi.text:
One of my favorite Mexican spots in the city.  The food portions are rather large, I almost always have to doggie bag it.  The salsa verde....yum.  Cucumber jalapeno margaritas...delicious and deadly.  I might have fallen down the flight of stairs leading to the bathroom last time a group of us had a handful of pitchers!  
  Of all the places I have been in the city...this spot has the largest selection of tequila.  Maria one of the bartenders is super knowledgable and will breakdown tequila with you for days!  She knows what's shes talking about!

poi.name: Johnny Brenda's
poi.text:
A stones throw away from my front door I have to make sure I don't abuse it's greatness.  Grab a quick drink, something to eat (Cuban Sandwich is my favorite), see a show, sit outside and critique fixed gear bikes, or shoot some pool, you can accomplish it all.  
   Reasonably priced, & usually a good crowd. They have a respectable selection of local beers, almost always have a rotating Dogfish Head option which puts a smile on my face.  
  I'm not hip enough for the juke box selection, but the venue upstairs is one of my favorite spots to catch a show.  Whether local or not, I find myself at this venue more so than any other in the city.  The space upstairs is straight up awesome!  Intimate, small balcony, and a nice sized bar.

poi.name: Parc
poi.text:
I had the luxury of grabbing brunch here with a g/f of mine over the weekend for the first time in a while, & it was just a enjoyable as I remember it.  We sat outside, people watched & made comments as though we were "Statler & Waldorf" from the Muppets while we shared several plates over the span of 2 hours.  
  I am not typically a bloody marys fan, but they are to die for here.  Perfectly balanced with a beautiful pepper kick to the face!  Some of the plates did seem small for the price point ie the poached eggs & asparagus but still good.  The beet salad was delicious, a healthy serving of beets & mixed greens.  My favorite; though simple was the parfait with mixed fruit.  The yogurt was heavy (a good heavy) with a nice array of recently harvested berries.  
  Although there seemed to be several servers & server assistants over seeing our table they failed to fulfill some simple requests we had throughout our meals; such as refilling our coffees & water, as well as getting us another basket of fresh bread for dipping purposes.

poi.name: Ekta Indian Cuisine
poi.text:
I used to be a huge fan of "Tiffin," however after Ekta opened I am yet to go back.  I have tried virtually everything on the menu and it is ALL DELICIOUS.  If you want it hot, they'll make it hot, if you want it atomic, they'll make it atomic!  
  My one complaint is that everything seems to be slightly over priced.  Granted the food is outstanding, but I feel as though every plate should be a 1-2 dollars cheaper.  I constantly find myself spending twenty to thirty bucks on myself, and most of the time it's take out.
  I am not a fan of reheated Indian, but all the food I get from here winds up being reheated at some point the following day, even the naan.  Reheated naan, never thought I would do it, but it has become a rather common occurrence.

poi.name: Heads & Tails Beauty Boutique
poi.text: This place is amazing!  I have been coming here for waxing services for a few years now.  I usually go to Lori Berger but have had appointments with other estheticians as well.  I have no complaints about any of the services I have received here and would highly recommend!  The space is cute, clean, and always smells amazing.  You will not be disappointed.

poi.name: The Rotisserie At the Porch
poi.text:
As far as food truck fare goes, I've had much better.  I feel it's appropriate to give them a review after giving them chance, after chance, after.. well, you get the point.  Today really did it for me, though.  I ordered their veggie burger, which is a fairly new item that has been added to their menu.  Let me just say do not EVER order this veggie burger.  It tasted like what I imagine my dog's food tastes like.. the dog food might even be better.  For all of the lunches I've had from this truck, there has legitimately been ONE thing that was good.. the BBQ pork wrap.  I will say that was delicious and filling.  My friends/co-workers have ordered the fish tacos on many occasions and seem to be pleased.  I haven't ordered them myself, so I cannot comment.

Overall, I am extremely disappointed in this truck.  As others have mentioned, we really had a good thing going with the rotating food truck schedule.  The food on all of the other trucks by far surpasses this ONE truck option.  You've let me down, The Porch, you've let me down.

poi.name: Spruce Internal Medicine
poi.text:
Some recent improvements in the practice:  new digs @ 8th & Walnut, walk in hours, and u can make appointments on-line. 
There were some recent communication problems between the office & my RiteAid pharmacy.  I finally asked for written Rx for all my meds, hand carried them to the pharmacist @23rd & Walnut.  Got 3 month supplies of most,w only a small copay.  That worked.
 The practice has (finally) gone totally electronic with patient records. 
Dr Nizen is a first-rate diagnostician. She listens extremely well.  I'm still very satisfied.

poi.name: Dom's Shoe Repair
poi.text:
Dom moved about a year ago, over to the other side of Walnut Street - a few doors in - towards Locust, on the East side of the street.  I've been gong to Dom since I moved into the neighborhood about 12 years ago.  He's re-heeled my walking shoes 3 or 4 times on each pair, and put new soles on most of them less often.  

To take the back off the sole of a new pair of Clark's driving shoes, so I can replace the heels regularly, he  charged $25 today.  He'll replace those heels 3 or 4 times, till I wear the rest of the shoe out, or get sick of them.

I took the shoes in Tuesday, said I needed them before Saturday.  We agreed on Friday; I went in at 3 today and they were ready - no problem.  I can't remember a time in the past dozen years that  shoes weren't ready when promised.  His work is good, prices were a bit lower than others in the area when i first went to him.  I have no idea how his prices compare now.  I'm completely satisfied with his work, his promptness and his pleasant manner.

poi.name: Ralphs Italian Restaurant
poi.text: Long-time fan of Ralph's here.  I adore sweetbreads, which are not on every Italian restaurant's menu.  So i go to Ralph's for sweetbreads.  I think the mushrooms in the dish are canned, but the sweetbreads are perfect, with a light sauce and are a huge portion.  I'm also crazy about their Fettucini Alfredo, which is the real thing, made with pasta, butter, parm and cream and nothing else.  My partner always orders spaghetti and meatballs - he's not a foodie and that's what he likes.  Since I order 2 entrees (so I'll have leftovers tomorrow), we don't get out of there cheaply, but I love the place.  And yes, it's a good place to bring visiting firemen - old-time ambience, attentive service, and Sarcone's bread.

poi.name: Spruce Internal Medicine
poi.text: Recently the practice hired a nurse practitioner.  She's very good with phone help, and usually has a same day appointment when Dr Nizen is overbooked.  I love NPs and Judy is a star.

poi.name: Spruce Internal Medicine
poi.text:
I've been seeing Dr Jennifer Nizen for a couple of years.  The only negative I've experienced  is getting through by phone, but I know from experience that you can expect that to be a problem with any U of Pennsylvania-affiliated practice. 
My search for an MD had the following criteria: Board certified in internal med or family practice, multiple physician office, Pennsylvania Hospital affiliation since all my records are there, personal referral from at least 3 sources (including a patient & a health professional),  50 years old or younger (for being up-to-date and so i won't outlive her worklife).  Then I made appts w 3 docs for initial visit and personal impression. I chose Dr Nizen after that extensive search.  
The office is clean, the staff are courteous and efficient; she does my Pap smear & breast exam.  She is very focused - if I make an appt for one issue, eg Pap exam, and bring up something else that seems important, we choose together which one has priority for that day & I make a later appt for the other.  I keep a running list of everything of concern & bring the list with me when I see her - I'm 68, with multiple health issues & she tracks them accurately & often asks about something not on my list. I'm a very satisfied patient.   I saw Dr Mazzotti the only time Dr Nizen was unavailable for an urgent issue & she too was focused and competent.  
They have e-mail access to make appts or ask a non-urgent question - that's convenient.   . I was a health professional for 30 years - I'm very picky about professional competence and behavior. This practice rocks!

poi.name: Chuck's Alibi
poi.text: It was OK , i wont be going back, people coming up to the table passing out flyers disrespectful the waitress not remembering our order, just messy. one and done.

poi.name: Ed's Pizza House
poi.text: Horrible, ordered off grub hub ans specifically put " no red sauce"  on my steak Stromboli , once the Stromboli arrives it has red sauce on it, so i called the girl hung up on me, i called back kept me on hold then once she picked up told me they would send another one out but i need to send the other one back, what kind of place wants food back from someones home who knows what they could have done with it, what are you gonna do with it sell it to another customer??  i told them cancel the order i didn't trust what they would do to my food i will never ever order anything from them again.

poi.name: The Groomin Room
poi.text: I brought my fur baby Vito to The Grooming Room for the first time on Saturday 6/18/16 and requested Rachel because of the reviews I read about her. I have my cosmetology license so I know a good cut even though I cut humans, I know when you get a quality cut or a shit one as I've been doing hair since 95'.  Rachel was very good. I am finicky about my baby's face and she cut it the way I requested. (I did tweek it a tiny bit but usually I have to clean-up the whole cut when I bring him home).  He looked and smelled wonderful.   I will be going back and Rachel will be the one I request again.  She really did the best job of any groomer I have ever brought him to. Thanks Rachel.

poi.name: La Colombe Coffee
poi.text: My husband and I LOVE pure black from La Colombe, the best stuff on earth. After we had a problem with our online order we contacted them and they refunded our money and sent us free coffee! Great service, we will be customers for life.

poi.name: Deluxe Hair Salon
poi.text:
After years of soul searching, bad haircuts and cockamamy salons I have been to in Philadelphia I finally found a salon I wanted to become a regular at. Not only are the aesthetics pleasing both inside and out but the warmness and friendly attitudes of the stylists makes you never want to leave.

I have seen Adrienne several times for a multitude of things. Shes taken my hair from long to short, turned a botched home color job into a saucy shade of brown (and them later turned me into a hot blonde) and has never let me leave until I was completely satisfied. Her fun attitude made me feel instantly comfortable sitting in her chair. Each and every appointment the result was exactly what I wanted she has a true understanding of what a fine art hair really is. SHES AMAZING. 

Did I mention there is complimentary tea and scalp massages? 

Deluxe is amazing, don't waste your time going anywhere else.

poi.name: Oscar's Tavern
poi.text: Best spot to grab a lager in Rittenhouse. Definitely would visit this circus again. Love the lightening. Love the vast prince selection on the jukebox. Love the food! Sometimes it does get full of creatures, but that just makes it better. I've been coming here for years. Super reasonable too!

poi.name: Free Tours By Foot
poi.text:
Bevan did an absolutely amazing job on the independence mall tour. He knew so much history and made it really interesting to listen to. If school had been like that I probably wouldn't have had my cousin do my homework!

It was a long tour (2 hours) but wasn't overwhelming or long winded. We learned so much and really enjoyed our time in Philly.

poi.name: Halal Gyro King
poi.text: The platter was very tasty and they give you more vegetables like onions, peppers, cucumbers, and tomatoes compared to other places. It's not my favorite cart but still a good stand by. I got the combo over rice with white and hot sauce, plus a drink, all for $5.00 :)

poi.name: Pho Street
poi.text: Went for lunch for the first time today. It's been so cold that I was really craving pho. This place is great! They have a variety of Vietnamese food including pho, broken rice, rice vermicelli, banh mi, and spring/summer rolls. There is a large area for seating and you can either order on a screen using a card or go to the counter to pay cash. I got the deluxe pho without tripe. It came out in less than 5 minutes and it is HUGE with tons of meat! It cost $11.50 but I will easily get two meals out of this generous portion. I suggest bringing a box for leftovers or you can always ask for one at the counter. The staff is very friendly and efficient. It is also very clean and there is an area to bus your trays and a bathroom inside. I will definitely be back to try the other menu items!

poi.name: Shang Hai 1
poi.text: Came in to try a few more dishes. The atmosphere is always very nice and calm here. The wait staff are friendly and attentive. I came here once with my sisters and their 5 kids, most around toddler age and everyone was extremely accommodating. I was a big fan of the Shanghai style udon and the braised pork over rice with egg.  Of course I always have to get soup dumplings and either the beef scallion pancake or regular scallion pancakes whenever I come. This is one of my favorite places in Chinatown!

poi.name: Marrakesh
poi.text: If you want to be culture shocked, go to Marrakesh. It feels like a really authentic, cultural experience, supplemented by delicious food. The staff and management have been incredibly courteous and solicitous both times I've attended. If you're squeamish about eating with your hands or having to share food, you'll probably want to skip.

poi.name: Dagwood's Pub
poi.text:
I come to Dagwoods all the time with friends and family. The food and service is great! This family owned restaurant really makes you feel at home. 

We started with some drinks and seafood apps. The clams in white were awesome! Perfect flavor and consistency. The broth was so good, I wanted to treat it as if it were soup. We also got some crabs to share, they were a good size and were warm and cleaned. 

I chose to get one of the specials, the Salmon, and WOW was I impressed. It was cooked so perfectly. A slight crunch on the outside (not burnt) and juicy on the inside. It was honestly the best salmon I ever had. There was a corn succotash on top and it came with orzo, because I can't have gluten I chose to sub broccoli. 

I am impressed with Dagwoods every time I come. They never fail to amaze and create a great experience weather it's your first time or you're a regular.

poi.name: Menchie's Frozen Yogurt
poi.text: This place was okay they didn't have many flavors but they did have some I've never tried before which was cool. I got there 45 mins before closing and felt like I was in the way of their cleaning duties, and even though I finished eating at 9:30 I felt uncomfortable hanging around. They had a lot of topping options but not peanut butter, this is my favorite topping to add so I'm hoping they get some in the near future.

poi.name: The Barbary
poi.text: I love going to this bar and especially on Monday nights. The music is always good and the dance floor is the spot to be. There are 2 floors that play different music genres so it's a place meant for anyone and everyone. Drinks are a good price and they have the city wide special. Bartenders are friendly too! On Mondays they have a photobooth, the "photobot 3000" this week the guy who runs it was out of town but when he is there it makes for a great time! I had a blast with my friends and can't wait to go back

poi.name: The Barbary
poi.text: I was a little disappointed when I arrived at the Barbary on Monday night and the photobooth wasn't there again. The music was good but up stairs was closed due to electrical issues and therefor there wasn't as much variety. Overall I still had a really great time and agree that it is the best spot in philly on a Monday night

poi.name: 3J's Food Market
poi.text:
I love love love 3J's it's a great spot to grab a quick bite, they serve breakfast all day and when I say their sausage egg and cheese with smoked gouda on GF bread is the best I've had in the city, I actually mean it. 

3J's is the kind of place where you're hungry but you don't know what you want. Just walk around the store, grab a bag of chips or an apple or some iced tea, take a look at their sandwich menu, and let 3J's TELL YOU what you want.

poi.name: Top Tomato Bar & Pizza
poi.text:
Top Tomato is a fun, laid back pizza spot with exceptional food and service. Their menu is versatile and has something for everyone, and the staff will treat you like family. The Forrest Theater is right across the street, if you're seeing a show its the perfect spot for a pre-show beverage.

I love coming here any day of the week, there's always something different going on that sets them apart from the other pizza spots/bars/restaurants near by. Karaoke, holiday themed parties, trivia and more. My friends came in for a halloween party and walked out with $100 for best costume! 

The Gluten Free pizza is so good as well as the cauliflower pizza. Every time I come in I have to get a pie to myself. My favorite is the white broccoli pizza, with marinara on the side.

poi.name: Urban Village Brewing Co
poi.text:
Came here quite a few times over the last year and the staff has always been excellent. Seemingly unfazed by the mask wearing as they performed their duties with attentiveness and care. Cheers to the staff!

OK, on to the menu. If you're not in the mood for an alcoholic beverage at the moment but still would like to sip on something, I would 100% recommend the Kombucha, weather you are dining in or taking out. For alcoholic beverages, the mulled cider is fantastic! 

Highly suggested by me is the cauliflower and smoked wings as an appetizer, garic parm is always my go to! The shaved rocotta salad is other worldly, how they get that ricotta so creamy is beyond what I can imaging for such a favored cheese. Personally, I would rather have 3 appetizers and try a bit of everything, rather than one big meal. 

For pizza (if you're GF like me) but the rest of your group isn't, simply smell the pizza. But do it in a way of appreciation for good food, not to torture yourself.

Three straight times in a row, I was waited on by a server named Lauren, she was fantastic!

poi.name: Charlie Was a Sinner
poi.text:
I have been wanting to come here for months and I finally made it last Wednesday for Sips! The service was incredible, 2 people came up to us and asked if they could get us a drink while we were waiting for our table. A man who looked like a manager even pulled up 2 bar stools so we didn't have to stand. Grade A customer service. 

I enjoy eating at a restaurant that displays pride in the food and beverages they are serving. Charlie was a sinner did just that! 

The food was amazing! I got the meatballs, which are made using seitan. I haven't had a real meatball in a few years but I am positive this one is better! My boyfriend, who is a relatively picky carnivore, thought it was amazing too. I really liked the mint infused water that was brought to each table. 

Overall, Charlie was a sinner exceeded my expectations and I will definitely be going back!

poi.name: Iron Hill Brewery & Restaurant
poi.text: The service was excellent! I love their menu too. I have a strict diet and it was easy to find something affordable and healthy. I got their spicy crab lettuce wraps. They were filling and satisfying but also light. The environment was nice and friendly also.

poi.name: Tavern On the Hill
poi.text: Very small intimate place with a piano player to set the mood. I went there with a friend to grab a drink and it was casual but elegant. I have yet to sit down and eat but look forward too it some time soon.

poi.name: Axis Pizza
poi.text:
Axis Pizza is very convenient- its 24 hrs and within walking distance of two universities. With that being said, it still manages to produce meals that are surprisingly quality. This place boasts about using fresh ingredients, and you'll see what they mean after your first bite. 

The food is simple, good, and fairly priced. Its my go to for late night meals and it hardly let's me down!

poi.name: Allegro Pizza
poi.text:
Great late night hang out spot for college students! You're served fast and given very generous portions as well. Although it does get a bit crowded and noisy, that is only to be expected given their location. 

I ordered wings and a side of fries. Both were very standard in taste, though they were not bland. Regardless of the flavor, they do give you a lot of food. If you ask for an order of fries, they fill an entire rectangular Styrofoam container full of them. In terms of drinks, (quite surprisingly)they have an extensive beer selection. 
I will definitely be back here and highly recommend this place to any Penn or Drexel student before and after the party!

poi.name: Xenos Candy 'N' Gifts
poi.text: Visiting Philadelphia from Chicago, and came into this store to purchase souvenirs for family. We found more than we even expected! We purchase so many items because the prices were great. We found souvenirs and even more! The owner was amazing and helped us pick out some of our gifts to take back home! We spent and hour there shopping and talking with the owner and didn't want to leave! Thank you for such a great experience in south Philly! -Nicole and Michelle

poi.name: National Car Rental
poi.text: This National site leaves much to be desired, especially compared to other National sites I've used. I rent a car very nearly every single week, so have a great deal of experience across the country. As an executive member, I have been very disappointed in what they offer as "executive" vehicles. Having rented a different car every week for more than four months, so far, I have had what I consider an "executive" vehicle only once or twice--pretty poor percentage. Lately all vehicle options in the "executive" area have more than 10,000 miles, with at least one over 30,000. The manager has no interest in customer service, preferring to quote rules and refuse to discuss options, rather than work with customers to resolve problems in a creative manner. I have been significantly overcharged, having to wait  for a resolution nearly 30 minutes, nearly missing a flight. The wait for a shuttle has been as long as 20 minutes, and I've been taken to the wrong terminal by an insistent shuttle driver resulting in a 40 minute journey back to the correct terminal and a missed flight. All in all, pretty mediocre.

poi.name: Pasqually's Pizza
poi.text: We have been going here for food and beer for a while, but will no longer bring our business to Pasqually's.  The owners allow a loud group of day workers to take over their joint several days a week to the point of fighting and breaking beer bottles.  Since complaining to the owners has brought no change, we will go elsewhere.

poi.name: Ralphs Italian Restaurant
poi.text: I was prepared for a tourist trap given the history and reviews, but ended up really liking this place.  We went around 9:30 pm on a Sunday so it wasn't crowded.  The menu is simple and good.  The marinara was flavorful without being sweet.  I like that the mushrooms in the pasta were fresh not canned, as with other old school places in Italian Market.  My friend had an excellent pasta with shrimp and artichokes.  I don't have a need to go to Villa Roma anymore since finding this place.

poi.name: Fairmount Pet Shoppe
poi.text:
I have been shopping here for two years.

Very friendly staff.  They always ask if I need help and are glad to show me the kind of product I am looking for.  They recently helped me select a new dog food as we try to trouble shoot my dog's recent stomach issues.  They were super knowledgeable and seemed to know way more than my vet when it comes to ingredients that could cause stomach upset.  The new food seems to be doing really well.  

I find their prices reasonable.  And, I love supporting a mom and pop store, especially since Petco has opened up not so far away.

Bonus that they have helped to adopt so many cats and provide great window entertainment on evening strolls past their store.

poi.name: Red Hook Coffee & Tea
poi.text:
This place smelled like a gym and was incredibly dirty.  Layers of fuzz on the counter where you fix up your coffee.  The floors looked like they had not been washed in a year.  I wanted to bolt the second I walked in the door.  But, my husband wanted some iced tea so we waited in line for a while and I got to observe the surroundings, which only reconfirmed why I will never be back.

The pluses are the people who work there were incredibly friendly and they have extensive vegan and gluten free options if you lean that way.

poi.name: Italiano's
poi.text: I was skeptical when someone at the dog park told me that Italiano's was better than Pops.  I am new to Philly and to water ice.  But after trying Pop's I saw no reason to go anywhere else.  Then I had a moment of insanity and thought, why not try to broaden my horizons?  I had Italiano's vanilla water ice.  It was fine.  A-ok.  But a bit too sweet, not subtle enough.  So five bites into it, I headed over to Pops.  Life is too short to eat a-ok water ice when you can go to Pops and have the best.

poi.name: Pizzeria Vetri
poi.text: Good pizza and salad.  Ridiculously small portions for the price.  Great hip hop music.  Free fizzy water.  Good waitstaff.  Free table side entertainment: the crazy Philadelphians who are sharing the table with you.

poi.name: Biscardi Vision
poi.text:
When it comes to healthcare, I am super picky and exponentially more stringent in my reviews than I am with a restaurant.  If you have a bad meal no big deal; if you have a bad doctor it is your health at stake.  

I found Dr Biscardi via yelp, which made me slightly nervous as this is not a place I usually come to for healthcare recommendations.  But I am so glad I found her. Dr Biscardi is extremely thorough.  She really takes her time.  I have been to see her twice for regular check ups and both times she spent at least a half hour with me.  She ran lots of tests, explained what they were, why she was running them, and what the results were.  I feel that she wants to help me see well but she is also looking out for my long term eye care and health.  She is smart and able to answer my questions - and I ask a ton of questions.  

I really like her personality.  I never felt pressured to buy anything.  She truly wants to collaborate with me in making sure I have the best contacts and eye glasses possible.  I feel comfortable telling her my concerns.

They have a wide variety of frame styles with something to suit everyone, though not a lot of depth to the selection within a certain style.   They are affordable compared to fancy pants boutiques.  The woman who works in the frames department knows her stuff.  She doesn't try to push something on you.  Instead she takes her time to make sure the frame actually fits your face and the spacing of your eyes.  I have been to every boutique frame store in center city and nobody has done that with me at any of those store.  This woman (sorry I forget her name) will tell you if the glasses are not a good fit for you.  They also don't try to rip you off by up selling features or lens processing that you don't actually need.

poi.name: Fleisher Art Memorial
poi.text:
I love this place.  I took the class Stitching and Surface.  I have taken other embroidery classes before and this was by far the best.  The teacher really knows her stuff and is able to give instruction on details about the art form that really make it easier to do.  She has a very realistic curriculum of projects.  She is great at answering questions.  You can tell that she really loves to teach and she really cares that you learn.  I hope all other art classes at Fleisher are as good as this one.  I am excited to continue taking more and more classes there.

Also, while I can afford the tuition, I think it is really important that they give a lot of tuition assistance to those who cannot.  All too often adult art classes are populated by people with deep wallets.  I think there is a great mix of students in this class.  

The whole building has a great vibe.  I find it really uplifting just to walk in the door.  And, I am not the kind of person who uses the words vibe or uplifting.  Way to go Fleisher.

poi.name: Essene Market & Café
poi.text:
I only duck in here when I am in the neighborhood, which is not often.  But I have made special trips for shampoos they carry that Whole Foods does not.  Their beauty section is pretty extensive.  The workers seem friendly.  The bathroom is gross.  But the rest of the place seems clean.

Hurray for small, independently owned health food stores.  They are a rarity these days.   This place is old school veggie, vegan, macro-food the likes of which I don't eat, but still appreciate is available for those who do.  Most health food stores these days are less about healthy and more about marketing overpriced packaged condiments with cute Etsy type packaging.  Not the case here.

poi.name: Anastacia's Antiques
poi.text:
Yes this place is fun and bizarre, but it is really so much more.  It is an excellent antique store for serious shoppers too.

Their prices are extremely fair.  I purchased from them a huge lighting fixture that I know would have been much more expensive elsewhere.  It is so nice to spend money on antiques without feeling ripped off or resentment towards the dealer.  Instead, the owners are super friendly and helpful.  They seem to gain real pleasure out of answering your questions and sharing their knowledge, yet they still give you plenty of room to roam on your own.  

They pack a whole lot into one space and arrange it in a way that is easy to see and I don't have to worry about knocking something over and break it.  And I find it unusual for a place to have such a wide ranging collection of both furniture, decorative items, hardware, lighting, and jewelery.  They do it all and do it well.

poi.name: Anthropologie
poi.text: Go for the architecture.  Wear a gas mask so you can breathe amid the horrible scented fumes.  Marvel at the ceiling, the staircases, the fireplaces.  Skip the poorly made overpriced clothing.  Don't give your money to the ultra-conservative guy who owns the chain.  Then leave.  If you want to skip the whole gas mask experience, just look in the windows at night and tilt your head up so you can see the ceilings.  Beautiful.

poi.name: John's Water Ice
poi.text: Had lemon and pineapple water ice.  Great texture but the flavor was very chemical tasting.  Bitter and overly sweet at the same time.  I'll stick with Pop's.

poi.name: The Shade Store
poi.text:
Pros: Made in the USA

Cons: Terrible customer service, limited options, cheap looking hardware

We are looking for shades for six rooms in our historic row house.  I was thrilled to see the The Shade Store opened in Philly.  I had walked by the one in NYC often but never had time to go in.  Unfortunately, at the Philly store, the customer service was horrible. We wanted cordless shades and their were such limited options. Plus, the mounting hardware on all of their shades looked cheap and was highly visible compared to other options I have seen elsewhere.  Even the pictures in their catalog look pretty bad when you check out the details of how they are hung.

The person who waited on us lacked so much product knowledge she had to traipse across the floor looking up answers online and calling supervisors for every single question we had.  She would forget the kind of shade we were looking for and give us misinformation, walk us down a design path and then 15 minutes into planning tell us she was wrong and we could not do it.  After an hour of dealing with this woman, she finally told us to just go online at home because she couldn't figure out how to use their website and couldn't answer any more of our questions about the shades we were going to order.  My god, why have a brick and mortar store if you are just going to tell people to go online and use your website?

I got home, went online, and discovered that we were unable to purchase her suggested cordless roller shades in the size we need.  I'm not sure why their are such stringent size limitations but they won't make cordless roller shades under 35" wide.  I want cordless for aesthetic reasons, but many people want them for safety with children.  These folks need to get with the program.  

Instead of using The Shade Store, I went with Drapery Design in Paoli.  Yes, it is far away, but they can come to your home for consultation and installation.  Their shades and drapes are handmade to order and their range of fabrics is much more extensive.  Plus, they had no problem working with my measurements.  The shades now hanging in my home are more substantial and higher quality than The Shade Store, were a bit less expensive, and the woman who we worked with knew the industry and her products inside and out. 

The Shade Store gets two stars because they are made in the USA, otherwise, this would be a one-star review.

poi.name: Zorba's Taverna
poi.text:
Don't do it.  The dolma taste canned.  The hummos is just so average.  The prices are way too high.  If you have ever eaten good Greek food you will be so disappointed.  I don't get how this place stays in business and has been around for so long.  I really love Greek food and this is in my neighborhood.  I wish it were better.  

The regulars (owners?) who sit at the sidewalk tables during the day belch choking cigarette smoke that you can smell from doors away.  However, they are so sweet and super nice to my dog.  Really good seeming people.  I wish I had something nicer to say about the restaurant.

poi.name: Claudio's Specialty Foods
poi.text:
While most people clamor here for the meat and cheese counter, I must give a big shout out to their dry goods as well.  They have an incredible selection of olive oil, vinegar, and salt that is fantastic quality and much better prices than neighboring stores.  I adore their olives too, pitted, unpitted, god damn good.  Also wonderful mackerel.

A brief word about their cheese:  Twice the guy behind the counter gave me tastes of cheese I was not even looking at.  Twice I felt as though I might just have to close up shop as an atheist and turn into someone who believes in heaven, pearly gates and all.  It was a transcendent experience and put Claudio's ahead of the Cheese Board in Berkeley as my favorite cheese shop.  Incredible.

poi.name: 30th Street Station
poi.text:
SUMMARY

Clean.  Well functioning.  Absolutely gorgeous.  Convenient.  


DETAILS

They don't wait until the very last minute to announce the track, so there are no massive herds trampling each other.  Instead they announce early enough for a civilized line.  And even though it is a relatively small station, it never feels packed or crammed.  I never have trouble finding a space on the great old fashioned benches either.  Some people on yelp complain about the restaurants here but it is a train station for crying out loud.  If you don't want Cosi or Au Bon Pain then eat before you get here.

BONUS

One of the side alcoves near the ticket booths has an outstanding plaster relief of various modes of transportation that is just an awesome piece of art that is not to be missed.

poi.name: Vientiane Café
poi.text:
Incredibly average Thai food.  Teeny-tiny, overpriced portions: $30 for pad see ew with tofu and rad nar with chicken.  Sizes so small we ended up needing another dinner two hours later.  What a waste of money!

It is a cute restaurant, which is the only thing this place has going for it, but that is not nearly enough for me.  Eating here pissed me off.

poi.name: Parc
poi.text:
There is absolutely nothing wrong with this restaurant, and I quite like the decor.  But for the price, I want outstanding food and impeccable service and this has neither. The atmosphere is also a bit zoo like.  It feels to me like a place where people from NJ and out of town go to when they want to feel like they are eating in a classy joint in the city.

My Lyonnaise had delicious dressing.  But the egg was really small and the yolk not runny or big enough to saturate the tiny hidden cubes of potatoes, so it didn't really come together the way a Lyonnaise should.

The skate wing was perfectly fine.  It came with lovely bits of artichoke heart that were fresh and hearty tasting.  I wish the brown butter were more delectable and something I wanted to sop up with my pieces of skate, but not the case.

Also, our waiter was very hesitant, standing at the side of the table never asking if we want to order.  He cleared our silverware after the first course and our second course arrived presumably hot but with no silverware for us to eat it.  We had to flag him down and when he brought silverware it was only for three settings not four, so again we had to wait to all start digging in.  It really is the small things that matter and this place lacked attention to detail.

 I would be happy with this quality of food were it in a small corner restaurant that didn't charge as much.  But with all the fuss and attitude about this place, they need to step up the quality.

poi.name: Fairmount Hardware
poi.text:
The people who work the floor are friendly and accommodating.  I wanted a refill head for a mop they sell.  They ordered it for me and was there three days later.  I walked in one day with black spray paint caked on my hands and asked what they sold that would remove it.  The guy asked if I just needed to take it off now.  I said yes and he steered me to their back room where he let me wash up with some magical soap and saved me the money of having to buy something I would probably never use again.  If I don't know where something is they show me.  If I need a solution they stick their mind to it.  The keys I have purchased there work fine.  

The reason I don't give them 5 stars is because my dad went to look for flat picture hangers and they didn't have any and it seemed like a pretty usual thing to find at a hardware store.  

Yes, the cashiers are unfriendly.  Who cares?  It is a friggen hardware store not a day spa.  Yes, the aisles are small and tight. Who cares? You live in a city.  If you want big isles support your evil big box hardwares stores instead.  You cannot find everything you need without asking. Well, that is an old fashioned hardware store for you.  You come in with your project and they show you around to what you need.

poi.name: Bistrot La Minette
poi.text:
Atmosphere is wonderful.  Food is average.  Bread is excellent.   If you are looking for a cafe in this neighborhood to have a nice long hang out lunch to catch up with friends, I would consider going here.  It is the kind of place that makes you want to sit and talk for hours.  If I were looking for excellent French food, this is not the first place that comes to mind.  

 I went for lunch so cannot comment on dinner.  I had a lyonnaise salad that was not good.  I couldn't finish it.  The frisee was wilted, the egg tasted soft boiled slimy rather than nicely poached, the dressing was nothing, there was no zing.  My partner had trout that was good.   

I noticed they had a private little dining room which could be great for events.

poi.name: Kabuki Sushi
poi.text:
This is a great place for a quick jaunt if you are in the convention center, tired of convention food, and don't want to deal with the lunch crowds in Reading Terminal Market.

This is the kind of place you go to when you want some rolls for lunch and are already in the vicinity.  It is not a place you go out of your way for or go to for dinner when you have a sushi hankering.  It is clean, efficient, and the rolls are decent enough.  It is not great sushi, it will not blow you away, but nor is there anything wrong with it.  The prices are very reasonable, the sushi is on the smaller side.

poi.name: Old City Movers
poi.text:
They moved our house this summer from a rental to our new home six blocks away.  Their three movers were efficient, skilled, and practiced.  They knew how to navigate tight corners, move around an extremely old and fragile banister, and didn't make a single scratch on our newly painted walls despite the narrow and winding halls.  They thought on their feet and helped solve lots of "how do we get this in here" problems, hoisting our deck furniture up to the roof deck with no problem.  Their rates were competitive.  It gave me pleasure to give each of the three guys a big tip.  

I checked out Broad Street and they were already booked.  I looked at Mambo but was turned off by how many reviews there were of scrawny artists who show up stoned and my conversation with the dude on the phone was all over the place.  My Old City Movers were scrawny artists too but they were whip smart, could lift the heaviest of items with no problem, and were not slackers in any way.  Dealing with the management on the phone was a piece of cake too.  The truck even arrived a few minutes early.

Our lead guy's name was Muffin, I think another dude was named Antoinne.  Sorry for butchering your names.  I would have loved to give you each a personal shout out on yelp.

poi.name: Tony's Luke
poi.text: Omg!!! I've never had a cheesesteak so good  I'm not a big eater so I ordered the junior philly; which is about 6 inches long, way more than enough if you want a good philly without feeling overly stuffed. I highly recommend this place.

poi.name: PrimoHoagies
poi.text: I don't know what so special about this place. I had classic chicken parm. It was okay, but I had expected something more than ok.

poi.name: Bui's
poi.text: The special Bui sauce.. hm.. tangy, spicy, it's a mixture of some not so common Asian flavor. Price is cheap, but flavor is just ok. Also it only opens rush hours, so if the doors are shut, it means shut. I tried meatballs and some steak sandwiches. They are okay. I think meatballs is little heavy with binders and hard to taste the meat. I can tell the sauce is definitely some jar brand.

poi.name: Federal Donuts
poi.text: Fried dough with lots of brown sugar. It's an experience, but nothing sort of amazing. Fresh donuts if comes out deep fryer within seconds always taste good. I went there late, so much of donuts were "sold" out. I don't know whether it's a gimmick or real. But the taste was ok. I got one with cinnamon (apparently it's retired now). But then, I think it's a bit overpriced,

poi.name: Hair Cuttery
poi.text:
Never, ever here. I forgot the name of the stylist. She was someone in 40's, medium length blonde, smoker (I could smell her while she was cutting my hair). She was extremely unprofessional especially when I told her that my side burn was uneven. I asked my friend to confirm this so that I wasn't looking crazy. She literally said that I can't do anything about your hairline. Yes, the hairline may be uneven, but the hair length should be evenly cut. One shouldn't be longer than the other. I didn't ask for money back, although my friend said that I should. 
If you want to preserve your hair, don't bother coming here.

poi.name: Dunkin'
poi.text: When I worked near University City, I stopped here occasionally, but 8 out 10 times, coffee always had strong burnt odor. I initially thought it was due to toothpaste or chewing gum. But nope, that's not the case. And few workers have rough attitudes (e.g., yelling, looking at you funny if it takes more than 10 seconds to get money out).

poi.name: Ralphs Italian Restaurant
poi.text: Bread was stale. Service was poor. I went there one night when it was pouring outside. The restaurant was packed. But meat sauce was blend. The noodles were overcooked. I'm beginning to think this whole 9th st Italian food is overrated.

poi.name: Scannicchio's
poi.text: Reservation would be good. We didn't make reservation on busy Friday evening, but the host asked us to wait for 10 minutes and were seated. I had seafood pasta and snails. The portion was generous and the service was friendly. But I would pick Pesto over this place.

poi.name: Copabanana
poi.text:
No. The bison burger was no good. First, charging for all different condiments doesn't make gourmet. Online prices were different from what I was told over the phone. Whoever picked up the picked up the phone was not professional.
Bison is very lean, so can be dry, but "medium" became a hard rock with no flavor. I would have added some mirim to tenderize. Chipotle sauce? Spicy and sour is not chipotle. 5 pieces of onion rings =$2. Unoriginal, badly cooked. Not coming back.

poi.name: Shee Yuan Chinese
poi.text:
I had the typical dishes, general tzo, shrimp toast, and szechuan beef. Awful. 
The chicken was mostly a batter, tasted old, no flavors in sauce. Shrimp toast was literally dripped in grease and burnt. The bee smelled funny and chewy. I just never had this kind of bad food. It's not even average tasting.

poi.name: New Delhi Indian Restaurant
poi.text: Nothing spectacular. Comme ci comme ça

poi.name: Rescue Spa
poi.text: I absolutely love this spa. It is my go to place for getting waxed. They are always quick and less painful than other places. Also they offer you tea or cucumber water when you arrive. It is a very serene and enjoyable atmosphere.

poi.name: Marmont Steakhouse & Bar
poi.text:
My husband and I came here for restaurant week. Rather than the typical three meal course for restaurant week, Marmont Steakhouse had four courses. We both started with the crab bisque. It was small but was meant as an appetizer rather than a soup course. It did have plenty of crab meat though. Much more than the typical bowl of bisque. For the next course I has the baked brie (my favorite part of the evening) and my husband had the cheesesteak spring rolls. He said they were good but definitely not as good as Continentals. For the main course my husband had a huge 12 ounce steak, which he said had a little fat but overall was juicy, delicious, and huge. I had the lobster ravioli. The ravioli dish was a little bland but not bad...just could have used some additional taste, which is why I requested some parmesan cheese for it. For dessert my husband had the chocolate mousse cake. It was very chocolatey and actually too large for my husband to finish after the other three courses. I finished with the bread pudding. It was very tasty and served hot.

Overall we had an excellent time at Marmont Steakhouse and would consider going back.

poi.name: Indique Virgin Hair Extensions
poi.text: I love having this store right here in the city. All I wear is Indique hair and to have this store so close is what I need! The ladies are very helpful in helping to choose hair although I always stick with my norm. The customer service here is on point and I will continue to utilize the service! Thanks Indique!!!

poi.name: Village Whiskey
poi.text:
I first heard of this place from a dude I know, and then I heard Craig LaBan called it the best burger in the city. That must be the $26 burger that I didn't have (mainly because I'm not a fan of bleu cheese, and I didn't want to be "that guy" to ask for a different cheese) because the Village Burger was good, but not exceptional.

I got the "Village Burger" (8oz, Sesame Roll, Tomato, Boston Bibb, House Made Thousand Island) with bacon and provolone (+$3). It was huge, could hardly fit in my mouth huge, and delicious, but I don't think I can call it the best burger in all of Philadelphia.

The duck fat fries were great. They were big, crispy, and hot on the inside. I'm going to get the sly fox cheddar sauce with them next time.

The whiskey list is HUGE. 

It's so small inside they don't have "sections" for the waitresses (or it might have been because only the bar and outside seating were busy). There's the bar that seats maybe eight people, though I didn't count (it was full), four or five booths (completely empty at 5:30pm), and a little counter that seats five or six in the back (empty as well). There's more seating outside than inside. After paying one waitress, another asked if I wanted another beer. I'm not sure if it's a plus that there's always someone checking on you, or a negative because they're unorganized? 

 I'll come back, but my main goal will be to try the extensive whiskey list, not a burger.

poi.name: Beck's Cajun Cafe
poi.text:
The alligator sausage po boy is nothing to write home about. It just tastes like regular old sausage, and the onions and peppers took up most of the sandwich compared to the tiny little sausage pieces.

The cashiers were clearly very unhappy to be working here.

You can find more flavorful sandwiches (with more meat) in Reading Terminal with more pleasant staff.

poi.name: Mac Mart
poi.text:
I've never even had the food truck, but I can tell they made absolutely no changes. The food isn't even decent for being a brick and mortar "restaurant." It tastes exactly how I imagine the food truck food to taste: cheap, fattening, with hardly any effort put in to make it, but hey, if that's your thing, then to each his own.

The inside is so tiny. I can only imagine what this place looks like during the lunch rush.

I can only see Mc Mart's value as a food truck for people who work nearby to get a quick lunch at, not as a legitimate counter-serve restaurant (so if you have more than a half hour, you're better off going somewhere else).

poi.name: Beck's Cajun Cafe
poi.text:
I came back because my friend wanted to come here for lunch. I had the Train Wreck Po Boy, and she has a Fried Shrimp Po Boy Wrap. 

It was pretty good, in a "cheesesteak from the pizza place down the street" kind of way. It supposed to be, "andouille sausage, steak, salami, onions, cheese, and creole mayo," but all you can taste in the steak and cheese with a little kick. The French baguette was pretty hard (inside and out), and I don't think they're fitting for a sandwich (unlike the *cough* rolls from that other place in RTM that are crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside *cough*). I think I would've preferred a wrap.

She let me try one of the fried "shrimp" that fell out. The breading was very tasty, but the "shrimp" tasted similar to that of what you'd find in a grocery store ramen noodles with fake shrimp package.

We also witnessed the "waitress" mess up everyone's orders and then do nothing to make up for it.

I stand by what I said last time, the Alligator Sausage Po Boy they're "famous" for was oddly devoid of alligator sausage and was mostly peppers and onions.

There's a reason there were four seats open at 1pm on a Sunday, You can do better in RTM.

poi.name: Urban Village Brewing Co
poi.text:
I've been here a few times now. I'll be honest. I'm caught somewhere between beer nerd from that one commercial with Danny Trejo and "I still won't drink Bud Light." I'm no expert, but I know enough about beer.

The more beers I try, the less great they become. I loved Sofa King, but all the others are just kind of okay to me. Also, I want to note that when they kick (run out of) beers, they weren't replaced with anything, so there were just fewer options on the menu. I really wish they had "backups" ready to take their places because, of the fewer options they had this last time, I wasn't thrilled with any of them. Of course, the ones they ran out of were the ones I wanted to try. 

I understand they are small, but they can't be that small (to not be able to produce beers to replace the kicked ones) because they have canned a few beers and were able to make enough to have them distributed to the suburbs.

The only food I've had here is the beer batter fried pickles, which were good. I'd come back if I were in the area, but I'm not gonna make a special trip again.

poi.name: Buena Onda
poi.text:
The third time I've been here, I finally tried the fish. I had one fried (you have the option fried or tequila lime glaze) Mahi Mahi. It was great. The Chipotle Remoulade didn't overpower the flavor if the fish. They're bigger than the carne, carnitas, and pollo tacos, too. 

The only problem is that the Mahi Mahi was piping hot, but my carne and carnitas were cold. I figure this is because it might take longer to make the fried fish tacos, but if that's the case, they shouldn't make them all at the same time. They should start the fish, wait, and then cook the meats. 

I also noticed there was less meat and more toppings on the carne and carnitas than the other times I've been here. This could be because those times it was dead, and this time it was sort of crowded (10 or so customers already eating, then another 5-10 came in after I ordered).

But still, this isn't enough for me to deduct a star (they're a true 4.5 but I rounded up). Buena Onda is the best.

poi.name: Mac Mart
poi.text:
Have you ever had a random craving for mac and cheese but didn't want to spend $20 on a full size serving or $10 on a side dish serving at a really cool bar? Then Mac Mart is the place for you! 

I had the Crabby Mac, which is a surprisingly good deal for just $9.50 plus tax (with bits of real crab!). The base mac and cheese itself is sooooooo cheesy! I've spent the same amount on side dish servings at bars, and they didn't have as much cheese as this! 

I imagine they make a lot and then keep it on a warmer because it's like a "fast food" place, right? I've had others (from fast food like places) that were burnt or dried out, but not here! I'm very surprised and happy with how it turned out. 

You also get a lot for the price. It's about a pound, I think someone else said before. And they have a lot of cool toppings like caramelized onions, fresh mozzarella, and FRICKIN TATOR TOTS!!

poi.name: Termini Bros Bakery
poi.text:
oh boy do I love their cheesecake, cannoli, La Colombe coffee, the list goes on! But on multiple occasions (even when there were only one or two other customers, I was ignored, and people who came after me were served before me (they'd get five stars if it weren't for this).

The women who work here are always so nice (when they don't ignore you).

poi.name: HipCityVeg
poi.text:
